entry.title: Extension Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping
entry.content:
Businesses require customization to meet their unique needs. If you use the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can add custom fields to support fiscal , providing enhanced flexibility for you.

What’s New?

This feature allows you to add custom fields to the fiscal document structure of supported documents using the Extension Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping (NFE_CLOUD_EXTENSIBILITY) Business Add-In (BAdI).

This BAdI enables the addition of simple and complex data types (fields, structures and tables) at any point within the document structure, ensuring effective handling of dynamic data. This functionality is available for cloud landscapes, via Developer Extensibility, supported by ABAP for Cloud Development. 

Supported Documents

Currently, NF-e (Electronic Nota Fiscal), NFS-e (Electronic Service Nota Fiscal, specifically for São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro), and CT-e (Electronic Transportation Document) are supported.

Known Restrictions: You can add custom fields and structures using the Extension Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping BAdI. However, you can't change the data already provided by SAP. Note that the new fields or structures you add only appear in the XML file if the Electronic Nota Fiscal (NFe) Authorize, Electronic Service Nota Fiscal (NFSe) and CTe Autorize APIs already support them.

Implementing the Business Add-In

The IF_NFE_CLOUD_EXTENSIBILITY interface is composed of the Add Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping (ADD_FIELDS) method, which returns the ADDITIONAL_FIELDS parameter containing a structure with the new fields added to the end of the segment being processed.  

  • IV_DOCNUM: The document number that allows selecting document data from the Brazil Nota Fiscal Document Data CDS view.
  • ID_DOCUMENT: The structure of the document sent for approval.
  • IV_BR_NFECLOUDEXTNMODEL: The type of electronic document being processed (NF-e, NFS-e or CT-e ).
  • IA_SEGMENT: The segment data of the document for which you’re creating the implementation.
  • IV_SEGMENT_PATH: The path of the segment being processed.
  • CD_ADDITIONAL_FIELDS: The structure that returns the new fields added to the document.

Filters

For performance improvements and easy implementation, the Extension Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping  BAdI has two filters:

  • Segment Filter (IV_SEGMENT_PATH): specifies the full path of the segment in the structure. For example, for the header segment, the IV_SEGMENT_PATH is "$.HEADER". Each document has a different root segment for the path of the structure being processed:
    • NF-e: J_1BNFE_S_AUTHORIZE_400
    • CT-e: NFE_CLOUD_CTE_MAP_AUTHORIZE
    • NFS-e RJ: IF_J_1BNFSE_TYPES=>TY_AUTHORIZE
    • NFS-e SP: IF_J_1BNFSE_TYPES=>TY_AUTHORIZE_SP
  •  NFe Cloud Extension Model (IV_BR_NFECLOUDEXTNMODEL): cloud extension model for which the BAdI implementation will be called. This parameter includes the NFe and NFSe filter values.

Known Restrictions: Currently, only NFS-e documents from São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro are supported.

Prerequisites

You have connected to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system in ADT (Eclipse-based ABAP development tools) and you're assigned to the DEVELOPER role.

How to Implement

You can create BAdI implementations through developer extensibility, which depends on filters.

1. Go to ABAP Development Tools (ADT) and create your own package. Make sure your package starts with Z in your namespace.

2. Create a new Transport Request for your package.

3. Choose the ABAP for Cloud Development Language Version.

4. Select the package you created, then choose New and Other ABAP Repository Object.

5. Select BAdI Enhancement Implementation and choose Next.

6. Enter a name that starts with the letter Z and if needed also your previously created package and find the Enhancement Spot that holds the released implementation.

7. Assign your BAdI Enhancement Implementation to an existing transport request, then the screen for the BAdI Enhancement Implementation appears.

8. Browse the BAdI you want to implement and enter a name for the implementation (starting with Z) and choose Add. 

This BAdI filters by segment path and model, allowing you to create separate implementations for each segment you need to extend.

Examples

Check the following examples on how you can structure your paths: 

  • Header of structure J_1BNFE_S_AUTHORIZE_400: PATH = "$.HEADER"
  • Issuer Address inside structure NFE_CLOUD_CTE_MAP_AUTHORIZE: "$.DOCUMENT_INFO.ISSUER.ADDRESS"
  • Prestador inside structure IF_J_1BNFSE_TYPES=>TY_AUTHORIZE: "$.INFRPS.PRESTADOR"
  • Endereço Tomador inside structure IF_J_1BNFSE_TYPES=>TY_AUTHORIZE_SP: "$.RPS.ENDERECOTOMADOR"

This enhancement empowers you to tailor  your documentation processes to better fit your operational needs.

entry.title: Step-by-Step Implementation Guide: SAP DRC Cash Flow Statements with Video Tutorials
entry.content:
Cash flow statements are one of the three fundamental financial statements that every business must prepare, alongside the income statement and balance sheet. While the income statement shows profitability and the balance sheet displays financial position, the cash flow statement reveals the actual cash movements in and out of your business. Understanding how to prepare and interpret cash flow statements—and choosing between the direct and indirect methods—is crucial for effective financial management.

This comprehensive guide includes detailed video tutorials to walk you through every aspect of implementing SAP DRC-based cash flow statements, from initial setup to advanced configuration and real-world examples.

 

1. What is a Cash Flow Statement?

A cash flow statement tracks the actual cash receipts and payments during a specific period, categorized into three main activities:

  • Operating Activities: Cash flows from core business operations
  • Investing Activities: Cash flows from buying/selling long-term assets
  • Financing Activities: Cash flows from debt, equity, and dividend transactions

The statement answers a critical question: "Where did our cash come from, and where did it go?"

1.1 The Two Methods: Direct vs. Indirect

The accounting standards allow two approaches for presenting the operating activities section of the cash flow statement:

The Indirect Method

The indirect method starts with net income and adjusts for non-cash items and changes in working capital to arrive at operating cash flow.

Typical Indirect Method Structure:

Net Income                            $100,000
Adjustments:
  Depreciation                        $20,000
  Increase in Accounts Receivable     ($15,000)
  Decrease in Inventory               $10,000
  Increase in Accounts Payable        $8,000
Net Cash from Operating Activities    $123,000

Advantages of Indirect Method:

  • Easier to prepare from existing financial statements
  • Less expensive to implement
  • Shows the relationship between net income and cash flow

Disadvantages:

  • Doesn't show actual cash receipts and payments
  • Less useful for cash flow forecasting
  • More difficult for users to understand actual cash movements

The Direct Method

The direct method reports actual cash receipts and payments from operating activities, showing gross cash flows.

Typical Direct Method Structure:

Cash Receipts:
  From customers                      $500,000
  From interest and dividends         $5,000
Cash Payments:
  To suppliers                        ($200,000)
  To employees                        ($150,000)
  For interest                        ($10,000)
  For taxes                           ($22,000)
Net Cash from Operating Activities    $123,000

Advantages of Direct Method:

  • Shows actual cash transactions
  • More intuitive and easier to understand
  • Better for cash flow forecasting

Disadvantages:

  • More expensive and complex to implement
  • Requires detailed tracking of cash receipts and payments

1.2 The Challenge: Implementing the Direct Method

While the direct method provides superior information, most companies avoid it due to implementation challenges. The main obstacle is that traditional accounting systems record transactions by account, not by cash flow categories. To prepare a direct method cash flow statement, you need to:

  1. Identify cash transactions among all recorded transactions
  2. Classify each cash flow into the appropriate category
  3. Match cash receipts and payments to understand the complete cash flow picture

This is where offsetting account determination becomes invaluable.

1.3 How Offsetting Account Determination Enables Direct Method Cash Flow

Offsetting account determination is a sophisticated process that automatically pairs each debit posting with exactly one credit posting in your accounting documents. Here's how it works and why it's crucial for direct method cash flow statements:

The Pairing Process

When you post a transaction, the system automatically:

  1. Identifies offsetting accounts for each G/L account line item
  2. Creates paired relationships between debits and credits
  3. Stores the pairing information for reporting purposes

Practical Example: Supplier Invoice

Consider a supplier invoice posting:

Before Offsetting Account Determination:

Account                          Debit    Credit
Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt    $1,000    -
Deferred Tax                     $180      -
Accounts Payable                 -         $1,180

After Offsetting Account Determination:

Pairing 1:
Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt    $1,000    -
Accounts Payable                 -         $1,000

Pairing 2:
Deferred Tax                     $180      -
Accounts Payable                 -         $180

This pairing process provides several advantages:

  1. Automatic Cash Flow Classification: Each cash payment can be automatically classified based on its offsetting account
  2. Detailed Transaction Tracking: You can trace exactly what each cash flow represents
  3. Accurate Reporting: Eliminates guesswork in categorizing cash flows
  4. Audit Trail: Provides clear documentation of cash flow sources and uses

 

2. Getting Started with SAP DRC Cash Flow Statements

The video tutorials that follow are designed to provide hands-on guidance for both technical implementers and business users. Each tutorial builds upon the previous one, creating a complete learning path that ensures successful implementation and adoption of the solution. All videos can also be accessed through this playlist: Step-by-Step Implementing SAP DRC Cash Flow Statements 

What You'll Gain from This Implementation Guide

By following this step-by-step approach, you'll be able to:

  • Understand the complete cash flow statement landscape and choose the right method for your organization
  • Configure both direct and indirect methods with proper SAP DRC framework setup
  • Implement advanced features like offsetting account determination for superior cash flow visibility
  • Handle real-world scenarios with practical examples and troubleshooting guidance

  • Clearing relationship between payment and invoice

  • Bank statement posting with bank in transit
  • Customer payment clearing through transit account
  • Customer invoice with revenue recognition

Sample Case 3: Goods Receipt Account (GR/IR)

  • GR/IR account usage in purchasing process
  • Complex clearing relationships

 

3. Conclusion

SAP DRC cash flow statements provide powerful financial reporting capabilities for organizations worldwide. The direct method offers superior cash flow visibility through offsetting account determination, while the indirect method provides a simpler implementation path.
